title: Is it acceptable to use 'Good day' as an opener to a formal letter instead of the trite 'Dear'? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, it isn’t acceptable. The formats of all formal and business correspondence have been established over 100 years ago — and taught to generations of secretaries by Pitman’s Institute and other global providers of secretarial training. Look at the secretarial typewriting workbooks published by Pitman’s and others for the established formats and general phraseology. UPDATE:— Crash course in salutations and closings for correspondence:— Most Formal (for very official communiques — rarely used now) Salutation:— “Sir” (or “Madam” if actually a female recipient)Closing:— “I remain / Yours faithfully” (not “Faithfully yours”)Formal (non-personal) “Dear Sir/Madam” and “To whom it may concern”“Yours faithfully”Business Formal (including email) “Dear Mr/Mrs/Miss/Ms Smith”“Yours sincerely” or “Sincerely yours”Regularity of communication (including email) “Dear [John, Mary]”“Sincerely,” “Kind regards” or “Best regards”Personal Formal “[My] Dear Uncle George”“Yours truly” or “Yours affectionately” (or “Yours truly/affectionately”)Personal Non-Formal Anything to openAnything to close

Is it acceptable to use "Good day" as an opener to a formal letter instead of the trite "Dear"? It depends on who you’re writing to. If it’s really formal, then “dear” is always a good fall-back. BUT - there are alternatives. I’m a Beatle nut since the boys first hit the airwaves. So your question instantly threw “Paperback Writer” into my brain.  But OH NO! That salutation has gone out of acceptance since the politically-correct era came along, as described in this article. Free Download: 17 Proven Strategies for LEAD GEN Marketing On Fire! — Email Alchemy Elite 2.0 This one may be more helpful: Best Letter and Email Salutations and Greetings to Use The library I worked for sent out invitations, announcements, solicitations for money, and many other letters that required a formal greeting. It was a bitch, for me at least, to decide what greeting was suitable for each letter. We had a database that stored every possible consideration for communicating with our friends and casual users and new contributors. This included a tab for salutations, and here’s where it got hairy. Say you have a widowed woman who goes by the “old-fashioned” name she’s used since her marriage to the guy in the ground. She insists we never refer to her as “Louise” but as “Mrs. Raymond K. Smith III.” We had to come up with a special coding for these women because if we had sent a missive to “Louise Smith” or to “Mrs. Smith” or to “Mrs. Louise Smith” - MAN, we could look forward to a reaming from Louise the moment she opened the envelope. Then we have the wife who needs to keep her identity intact. She’s either “Betty Amelia Zygmunt” or “Betty Amelia Zygmunt-Bono.” Could that be more confusing? and how do you format that in a letter? She’s called to complain no matter what we call her. We’re scared shitless to send another formal letter with any sort of salutation - and then there’s the problem, as with other cases of salutation ambiguity, where the husband (bless his soul) needs a salutation of his own, separate and distinct from Betty Amelia’s. That requires two lines of names, just another brick on a marketing person’s head. Gratitude to all husbands who don’t give a damn how they’re addressed. Well, except when it comes to titles, family add-ons, or some weird shit no one uses anymore - Sir, Esq, to name a couple. Lesser headaches involve mostly women who simply refuse to be a “Miss.” No problem; we deleted all “Miss” from the database and replaced it with “Ms.” Job well done. Who can argue with “Ms.?” Yep, someone can. Someone who has issues with any sort of salutation because they separate the sexes. OMG! We were running out of options in the database, resorting to a Word file with all these oddball requests/demands, then having to check all mailing lists against that file. Am I paid enough for this? What began as a simple and basic question raked up these memories, and would be more if I’d stop for another think-through. I hope my answer has given a peek into the complexity of a problem most people don’t have to fuss over. Good luck with pleasing all of the people all of the time.
